Performance Data Examples

Source: vignettes/performance_table_examples.Rmd
performance_table_examples.Rmd
library(rtichoke)

It is useful to work with Performance Datas for most functions in {rtichoke}.

There are several different cases for different Performance Datas:

1. One model for one population

When the user just want to observe the performance of one model.

One can use a single vector as an input for the probs argument:


one_pop_one_model_as_a_vector <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = example_dat$estimated_probabilities,
  real = example_dat$outcome)

head(one_pop_one_model_as_a_vector)
#>   threshold TP TN FN  FP sensitivity  FPR     lift specificity       PPV NPV
#> 1      0.00 50  0  0 100           1 1.00 1.000000        0.00 0.3333333 NaN
#> 2      0.01 50 51  0  49           1 0.49 1.515152        0.51 0.5050505   1
#> 3      0.02 50 55  0  45           1 0.45 1.578947        0.55 0.5263158   1
#> 4      0.03 50 61  0  39           1 0.39 1.685393        0.61 0.5617978   1
#> 5      0.04 50 67  0  33           1 0.33 1.807229        0.67 0.6024096   1
#> 6      0.05 50 67  0  33           1 0.33 1.807229        0.67 0.6024096   1
#>   positives        NB predicted_positives_percent
#> 1       150 0.3333333                   1.0000000
#> 2        99 0.3300337                   0.6600000
#> 3        95 0.3272109                   0.6333333
#> 4        89 0.3252921                   0.5933333
#> 5        83 0.3241667                   0.5533333
#> 6        83 0.3217544                   0.5533333

one_pop_one_model_as_a_vector_enforced_percentiles_symmetry <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = example_dat$estimated_probabilities,
  real = example_dat$outcome,
  enforce_percentiles_symmetry = T)

head(one_pop_one_model_as_a_vector_enforced_percentiles_symmetry)
#>      threshold predicted_positives_percent TP  TN FN FP sensitivity FPR lift
#> 100% 0.9962154                        0.00  0 100 50  0        0.00   0  NaN
#> 99%  0.9936659                        0.01  1 100 49  0        0.02   0    3
#> 98%  0.9936659                        0.02  1 100 49  0        0.02   0    3
#> 97%  0.9861045                        0.03  5 100 45  0        0.10   0    3
#> 96%  0.9823690                        0.04  5 100 45  0        0.10   0    3
#> 95%  0.9823690                        0.05  5 100 45  0        0.10   0    3
#>      specificity PPV       NPV positives          NB
#> 100%           1 NaN 0.6666667         0 0.000000000
#> 99%            1   1 0.6711409         1 0.006666667
#> 98%            1   1 0.6711409         1 0.006666667
#> 97%            1   1 0.6896552         5 0.033333333
#> 96%            1   1 0.6896552         5 0.033333333
#> 95%            1   1 0.6896552         5 0.033333333

Or alternatively a list with a single vector. In that case a column named “model” will be added to the Performance Data, it is recommended to name the vectors:


one_pop_one_model_as_a_list <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = list("Logistic Regression" = example_dat$estimated_probabilities),
  real = example_dat$outcome)

head(one_pop_one_model_as_a_list)
#>                 model threshold TP TN FN  FP sensitivity  FPR     lift
#> 1 Logistic Regression      0.00 50  0  0 100           1 1.00 1.000000
#> 2 Logistic Regression      0.01 50 51  0  49           1 0.49 1.515152
#> 3 Logistic Regression      0.02 50 55  0  45           1 0.45 1.578947
#> 4 Logistic Regression      0.03 50 61  0  39           1 0.39 1.685393
#> 5 Logistic Regression      0.04 50 67  0  33           1 0.33 1.807229
#> 6 Logistic Regression      0.05 50 67  0  33           1 0.33 1.807229
#>   specificity       PPV NPV positives        NB predicted_positives_percent
#> 1        0.00 0.3333333 NaN       150 0.3333333                   1.0000000
#> 2        0.51 0.5050505   1        99 0.3300337                   0.6600000
#> 3        0.55 0.5263158   1        95 0.3272109                   0.6333333
#> 4        0.61 0.5617978   1        89 0.3252921                   0.5933333
#> 5        0.67 0.6024096   1        83 0.3241667                   0.5533333
#> 6        0.67 0.6024096   1        83 0.3217544                   0.5533333

one_pop_one_model_as_a_list_enforced_percentiles_symmetry <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = list("Logistic Regression" = example_dat$estimated_probabilities),
  real = example_dat$outcome,
  enforce_percentiles_symmetry = T)

head(one_pop_one_model_as_a_list_enforced_percentiles_symmetry)
#>                    model threshold predicted_positives_percent TP  TN FN FP
#> 100% Logistic Regression 0.9962154                        0.00  0 100 50  0
#> 99%  Logistic Regression 0.9936659                        0.01  1 100 49  0
#> 98%  Logistic Regression 0.9936659                        0.02  1 100 49  0
#> 97%  Logistic Regression 0.9861045                        0.03  5 100 45  0
#> 96%  Logistic Regression 0.9823690                        0.04  5 100 45  0
#> 95%  Logistic Regression 0.9823690                        0.05  5 100 45  0
#>      sensitivity FPR lift specificity PPV       NPV positives          NB
#> 100%        0.00   0  NaN           1 NaN 0.6666667         0 0.000000000
#> 99%         0.02   0    3           1   1 0.6711409         1 0.006666667
#> 98%         0.02   0    3           1   1 0.6711409         1 0.006666667
#> 97%         0.10   0    3           1   1 0.6896552         5 0.033333333
#> 96%         0.10   0    3           1   1 0.6896552         5 0.033333333
#> 95%         0.10   0    3           1   1 0.6896552         5 0.033333333

2. Several models for one population

When the user wants to compare several models.

One needs to use a list with a vector for each population as an input for the probs argument. it is recommended to name the vectors:


one_pop_three_models <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = list("Good Model" = example_dat$estimated_probabilities,
               "Bad Model" = example_dat$bad_model,
               "Random Guess" = example_dat$random_guess),
  real = example_dat$outcome)

one_pop_three_models_enforced_percentiles_symmetry <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = list("Good Model" = example_dat$estimated_probabilities,
               "Bad Model" = example_dat$bad_model,
               "Random Guess" = example_dat$random_guess),
  real = example_dat$outcome, 
  enforce_percentiles_symmetry = T)

3. Several Populations

When the user wants to compare model performance on different populations. Might be usefull when the user wants to check the consistensy of the model among different populations, a test-train split or fairness analysis might be good use cases.

One needs to use a list with a vector for each model as an input for the probs argument and for the real argument. A column named “population” will be added to the Performance Data, it is recommended to name the vectors:


train_and_test_sets <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = list("train" = example_dat %>%
                 dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "train") %>%
                 dplyr::pull(estimated_probabilities),
               "test" = example_dat %>% dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "test") %>%
                 dplyr::pull(estimated_probabilities)),
  real = list("train" = example_dat %>% 
                dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "train") %>%
                dplyr::pull(outcome),
              "test" = example_dat %>% 
                dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "test") %>%
                dplyr::pull(outcome)))

head(train_and_test_sets)
#>   population threshold TP TN FN FP sensitivity       FPR     lift specificity
#> 1      train      0.00 28  0  0 68           1 1.0000000 1.000000   0.0000000
#> 2      train      0.01 28 36  0 32           1 0.4705882 1.600000   0.5294118
#> 3      train      0.02 28 39  0 29           1 0.4264706 1.684211   0.5735294
#> 4      train      0.03 28 43  0 25           1 0.3676471 1.811321   0.6323529
#> 5      train      0.04 28 46  0 22           1 0.3235294 1.920000   0.6764706
#> 6      train      0.05 28 46  0 22           1 0.3235294 1.920000   0.6764706
#>         PPV NPV positives        NB predicted_positives_percent
#> 1 0.2916667 NaN        96 0.2916667                   1.0000000
#> 2 0.4666667   1        60 0.2882997                   0.6250000
#> 3 0.4912281   1        57 0.2855017                   0.5937500
#> 4 0.5283019   1        53 0.2836125                   0.5520833
#> 5 0.5600000   1        50 0.2821181                   0.5208333
#> 6 0.5600000   1        50 0.2796053                   0.5208333

train_and_test_sets_enforced_percentiles_symmetry <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = list("train" = example_dat %>%
                 dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "train") %>%
                 dplyr::pull(estimated_probabilities),
               "test" = example_dat %>% dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "test") %>%
                 dplyr::pull(estimated_probabilities)),
  real = list("train" = example_dat %>% 
                dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "train") %>%
                dplyr::pull(outcome),
              "test" = example_dat %>% 
                dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "test") %>%
                dplyr::pull(outcome)), 
  enforce_percentiles_symmetry = T)

head(train_and_test_sets_enforced_percentiles_symmetry)
#>          population threshold predicted_positives_percent TP TN FN FP
#> 100%...1      train 0.9962154                        0.00  0 68 28  0
#> 99%...2       train 0.9937934                        0.01  1 68 27  0
#> 98%...3       train 0.9936659                        0.02  1 68 27  0
#> 97%...4       train 0.9900544                        0.03  3 68 25  0
#> 96%...5       train 0.9837787                        0.04  4 68 24  0
#> 95%...6       train 0.9736665                        0.05  5 68 23  0
#>          sensitivity FPR     lift specificity PPV       NPV positives
#> 100%...1  0.00000000   0      NaN           1 NaN 0.7083333         0
#> 99%...2   0.03571429   0 3.428571           1   1 0.7157895         1
#> 98%...3   0.03571429   0 3.428571           1   1 0.7157895         1
#> 97%...4   0.10714286   0 3.428571           1   1 0.7311828         3
#> 96%...5   0.14285714   0 3.428571           1   1 0.7391304         4
#> 95%...6   0.17857143   0 3.428571           1   1 0.7472527         5
#>                  NB
#> 100%...1 0.00000000
#> 99%...2  0.01041667
#> 98%...3  0.01041667
#> 97%...4  0.03125000
#> 96%...5  0.04166667
#> 95%...6  0.05208333
